question.title: Gradle and Java build jar
question.body:
Does Gradle support backward compatibility for build Java? For example, can Gradle version 8.5 build Java 11 or Java 8 jar files?

Generally, how to choose Gradle to build a Java code for JDK 11?

answers.body:
tl;dr

Use Java toolchains.

Read the Fine Manual

See Targeting a specific Java version in the Gradle User Manual.

In order of preference, quoting from the doc, as of Gradle version 8.13, your options are:

  • Using Java toolchains is a preferred way to target a language version. A toolchain uniformly handles compilation, execution and Javadoc generation, and it can be configured on the project level.
  • Using release property is possible starting from Java 10. Selecting a Java release makes sure that compilation is done with the configured language level and against the JDK APIs from that Java version.
  • Using sourceCompatibility and targetCompatibility properties. Although not generally advised, these options were historically used to configure the Java version during compilation.

Gradle 8.5 and Backward Compatibility for Building Java

  • The "Compatibility Matrix" (docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/compatibility.html) page within the user guide provides a detailed overview of the tested and officially supported Java versions for various Gradle releases.
  • This matrix outlines the compatibility for both running the Gradle build process itself and for utilizing Java toolchains to compile and test code against specific JDKs.
  • While the compatibility matrix offers a solid foundation for understanding supported configurations, it is important to note that Gradle's toolchain support often extends its ability to work with newer Java versions even before they are explicitly listed as fully supported for running Gradle. This proactive approach allows developers to leverage newer Java features with potentially older Gradle versions, although official support guarantees a higher level of stability and testing.
  • Referring to the compatibility matrix, Gradle 8.5 demonstrates robust compatibility with Java 11. The matrix explicitly states that Gradle 8.5 supports running on Java versions ranging from 8 up to 23.

Role of Java Toolchains

A key feature enabling Gradle's flexibility in handling different Java versions is the concept of Java toolchains.

  • Toolchains allow Gradle to utilize a specific JDK for compiling, testing, and running Java code, independent of the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) that Gradle itself is running on.
  • This decoupling is crucial for projects that need to target a particular Java version while the build environment might have a different Java version configured.
  • Java toolchains are configured within the build.gradle or build.gradle.kts file using the java.toolchain block. For example, to specify that a project should be built using Java 11, the following configuration can be added:
java {
    toolchain {
        languageVersion = JavaLanguageVersion.of(11)
    }
}
  • Gradle is intelligent enough to automatically detect locally installed JDKs that match the specified requirements. Furthermore, if a suitable JDK is not found locally, Gradle can be configured to automatically download it from configured toolchain download repositories. This feature significantly simplifies the management of JDKs for different projects and ensures that the build process consistently uses the intended JDK, regardless of the underlying environment.

Resources and Further Reading

  • Gradle Compatibility Matrix:https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/compatibility.html
  • Gradle User Guide - Java Toolchains: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/toolchains.html
  • Gradle Release Notes: https://gradle.org/releases/
  • Gradle Feature Lifecycle: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/feature_lifecycle.html
  • End of Life for Gradle: https://endoflife.date/gradle
  • Building Java Projects: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/building_java_projects.html

question_comments.body: @Robert Update: targetCompatibility is the least preferred of three ways to target a version of Java. See manual.

Gradle does not compile and build jar files, it just delegates that job to the configured Java compiler. And Java compiler can be configured to build classes for older Java versions (up to a certain degree). Just look for the targetCompatibility config option. Note that it is ul to you to make sure the code doesn't make use of functions that are not available in the older Java version.
Here there is a compatibility matrix. It may be useful. docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/compatibility.html
